channel.title: Combined Politepol Feed
channel.description: Merged feed from multiple Politepol sources

item.title: In Graphics | Why are bus fires on the rise in India?
‘Sex warfare’: How Russian, Chinese spies are luring techies and stealing Silicon Valley secrets
Anti-Trump protesters are wearing inflatable frog costumes. Here's why
Why 25-year-old is suing Pakistan over ‘period tax’
Poop cameras are the new health fad. Are they simply a waste?
Why Trump’s ballroom in the White House is unlike any other renovation by US presidents
West still clings to intellectual colonialism while Indians face scholastic apartheid
item.description: It is impossible to ignore that Western scholars—overwhelmingly White—have exercised an unrestrained entitlement to interpret, categorise, and often diminish Indian culture, religion, and society with little pushback from Indian institutions themselves

item.title: Small state, deft diplomacy: How Qatar has raised its ‘smart power’
item.description: The ability to talk to both sides is Doha’s rarest currency. If any Arab state can help reduce the reflexive hostility between Tehran and the Arab world, it is Qatar

item.title: How Yunus’s regime has driven Bangladeshi Army towards internal rift and radicalisation
item.description: Under Muhammad Yunus’s weak and misguided interim rule, the once-disciplined Bangladesh Army now stands divided, torn between secular patriots, political opportunists, and Islamist sympathisers

item.title: India isn’t heading for revolution, it’s redefining democracy
item.description: India’s transformation is noisy, complex, and self-driven, but it is not anarchic. The ‘revolution’ underway is one of empowerment: digital inclusion, education, start-up mobility, and global ambition

item.title: Bangladesh on the brink: How the Yunus regime’s Islamist purge threatens the military
item.description: Unless Bangladesh’s democratic and security institutions are defended, the world may soon confront a new Islamist axis anchored in Dhaka, destabilising the entire Indo-Pacific theatre.

item.title: China’s influence operations and coercive diplomacy: India’s response offers a blueprint for democracies
item.description: China’s influence operations and coercive diplomacy, as evidenced by actions in the United States, Britain, Canada, Japan, the Philippines and India, represent a systemic challenge to the international order
